metadata.sermon_start_end: I was a fully grown man before I realized that it was a mistake to call the books of the twelve prophets whose writings bring the Old Testament to its close "minor prophets." [...] O Lord, revive thy work, give us strength, give us hope, and give us faith. To whom else can you turn? To whom else can I turn? Where else is there to look? "O Lord, revive thy work in the midst of the years."

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to isolate what is unique to Habakkuk 3:2. Instead of finding what is 'nowhere else in the Bible,' the preacher uses the text as a springboard for general themes of theodicy and social justice. The first third of the sermon is a generic introduction to the Minor Prophets rather than an actualization of the specific pericope.
quotes: Where in the Bible short of Calvary does one come upon a picture of the love of God more touching than in the parable of the likeness of Hosea's love...
I take that 'make known' to be — how do the grammarians put it? —elliptical.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Eliminate the lengthy introduction about other Minor Prophets. Focus exclusively on the unique tension of Habakkuk's prayer—the specific 'middle' between the vision and the reality—without immediately diluting it with other biblical examples.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the historical context (600 BC) and the theological category of theodicy. However, the exegesis remains on the surface. The 'elliptical' nature of the Hebrew text is mentioned but not deeply explored in its original cultic or prophetic setting.
quotes: In Habakkuk we come across words written maybe six hundred years before the birth of Christ...
This book of Habakkuk deals with what the theologians call 'theodicy'...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the linguistic and historical analysis. Instead of just defining 'theodicy,' explain the specific Babylonian threat Habakkuk faced to make the 'misery' concrete rather than philosophical.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon. It is concrete, naming specific social issues (apartheid, single-parent families in the US) and personal psychological states (loss of verve, mid-life disillusionment). It avoids 'general truths' by naming names like Daniel Moynihan and Bill Moyers.
quotes: Sixty percent of our black children are born out of wedlock. Fifty percent of the prison population of America today is black...
At Dartmouth last week... a new crop of conservative students took sledgehammers and tore down the symbols of opposition to apartheid...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows directly from the text's unique 'middle years' concept rather than using the text as a hook for a general social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional 'block' structure: introduction to prophets, then exegesis of theodicy, then contemporary application. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' in one movement; rather, the text is explained and then the preacher moves on to 'real life' examples.
quotes: I never like to keep things on a broad scale. It is so in each of our lives when we start out...
But in the meantime, dreadful things go on. Bad news comes.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the contemporary examples (like the Dartmouth incident) directly into the explanation of Habakkuk’s 'watchtower' to show how the text 'expounds' the hearer.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' is well-articulated, both socially and psychologically. 'Redemption' is present but leans heavily on human 'strength' and 'hope' rather than an objective work of God. 'Gratitude' is the frame (the title), but the sermon feels more like a lamentation.
quotes: It's the third quarter, we're behind, and it doesn't look like we can catch up before the final whistle!
O Lord, revive thy work, raise up my bowed-down head, dry my weeping eye, and renew my strength.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify that 'redemption' is not just 'new strength' for the human subject, but a specific act of God that is 'outside' the human, as Dekker requires.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon lacks the 'seriousness of being lost' in the Dekkerian sense. While it mentions the 'entrenchments of evil,' it assumes a 'Monday-morning side of resurrection' where triumph is inevitable. The 'two ways' (destruction vs. life) are not presented as a choice for the hearer.
quotes: We have no choice except to believe that God's cause will triumph.
It's textured into us, somehow goodness will win!
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the possibility of 'being lost in time'—the real danger that God's work is *not* revived because of human unfaithfulness or the 'broad way' of the zeitgeist.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos' and the 'yes' to the 'no' of Friday. However, the connection to the specific text of Habakkuk 3:2 is somewhat forced. Christ is used as a general theological solution rather than being found specifically through the 'garment' of this passage.
quotes: We have seen truth incarnate, truth in flesh, crushed to earth and rise again.
He will be all and all; the last enemy to be destroyed is death.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the 'revival of work' in Habakkuk specifically to the person of Christ as the 'work' of God, rather than moving to a general Easter theology.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker’s 20-minute minimum. This lack of 'breadth' results in a rushed conclusion that relies on emotional appeals and song lyrics rather than sustained theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to reach the 20-minute mark, allowing for more 'depth' in the 'breadth' of the argument.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s ideal primarily due to its lack of textual specificity and its failure to present the 'two ways.' The first third is wasted on a general introduction to the Minor Prophets. While the contemporary application is concrete and avoids 'general truths,' the sermon lacks the necessary length (under 20 minutes) and the 'seriousness of being lost.' It relies too heavily on an inevitable 'resurrection' optimism that bypasses the radical choice of the two ways.
strengths: Concrete application: The preacher names specific social and political realities, avoiding the 'forbidden general truths.'
Psychological depth: The description of the 'middle years' and the loss of youthful verve effectively addresses the human subject's misery.
weaknesses: Lack of textual specificity: The sermon spends too much time on other biblical books and general theodicy rather than what is unique to Habakkuk.
Absence of the 'two ways': The sermon assumes salvation is 'textured into us,' which Dekker warns against as taking neither God nor man seriously.
Insufficient length: At under 20 minutes, it lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletical 'depth'.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate speech with strong social commentary, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense because it fails to recreate the specific Bible passage into a unique, current word and lacks the gravity of the two ways.
